Uh, technical UI design is somewhat of a

basically a bridge between art and
engineering.
Those disciplines tend to speak
different languages. So, we translate
responsible for UI implementation in

that means with Fortnite and Unreal

as the presenter of this talk, it's of

So, the first thing we're going to go

After that, we'll talk about

So, what is a view model? We use view
models within the MVVM architectural
pattern, which stands for model view,
view model. It allows us to separate out
the view or the screen from the data and
data source. Previously in Unreal, most
teams were binding code directly to
specific widget elements. That direct
binding method hit limitations of scale.
Long-term ramifications weren't really
considered when it was proposed as a
solution. So, view models aimed to solve
those problems. It is still technically
a beta feature in Unreal, but Fortnite's
been using it for a while now, so I'll
let you decide your risk tolerance with
that in mind.
Since it is a beta feature, though,
you're going to have to go into the
plugins window and turn it on before
you'll be able to find and use it in
UMG.
As a little heads up, you're going to
hear me say VM a lot during this talk.
Just know that I'm using it as an
abbreviation for view model.
So, I want you to think of your view
model as a pantry. So, when you're
cooking, you can use the same
ingredients to make a number of
different meals. So, let's say I look at
my pantry and I've got tortillas,
chicken, cheese. I can make tacos,
quesadillas, or burritos all using those
same ingredients. That same sort of idea
is what's great about view models. They
provide the data for you to use however
you like without having to ask for any
changes from an engineer.
So raise your hand if you've ever worked
with artists or designers that have
seemingly out of nowhere asked you to

Yep. Probably at least half the room. Um
so maybe they said it's not meeting

or they just don't like how it looks.
while MVVM can make that redesign

So, let's look at a Fortnite example of
the same data being used to create

One of the changes that we made that's

So now on the right side of the screen,

with MVVM, there's no code being tied

can create your view model in blueprint

I wanted you to know that these options

So, there's currently five options for
getting or creating your VM instance.
It's important to understand when to use
which option based on your use case and
preferences.
So, the first option is manual where you
set your VM yourself. This can be done
through blueprints or binding to another
VM that has a VM within it, which I like
to call VMion.
Create instance is something we don't
often use on Fortnite because we
generally want a VM that's already
populated with data, but you can use
that if you want an instance that's
specific to the widget that you're in.
For global view model collection, you
add your VM instance to the collection
and then specify the view model
identifier by typing in the string to
get the one that you want.
Next is property path. With property
path, you have a couple options to get
your VM from elsewhere.
The first is to reference a VM that
you've already gotten in your widget
that has a child VM, and then you can
create a path to that child VM. The
second is to create or reference a
function that will get the VM from
another source for you.
Resolver is where you use a resolver
asset which is encode in our case on
Fortnite to automatically get or create
the VM instance for you. This is
generally used when you only have one
instance that's going to exist to the VM
that's globally shared.
then you're able to get it automatically
since you don't have to specify which
instance of the VM that you're needing.
If you want more detail on any of these

The two creation options that we use the
most on Fortnite are manual and
resolver.
That's because when we want a specific
VM, we find that we generally have a
good way to get it manually in the
context of the widget. And if we want a
global VM, then resolver is just the
most userfriendly way of getting or
creating that instance. All right. Now,
once you have your VM, you need to bind

Here's an example of a very simple

you can probably tell the benefit icon
is another one of those variables in
that VM.
Now, sometimes the way that you want to
use your value from the VM is too

So, for this example, I want to set the
text on the highlight in the bottom
right of these tiles. So, you see like
that five to claim in yellow.
I need to take a few things into
consideration to do that.
First, I need to know is the tile double

double wide, then I have enough space to

then I just want to use the number
itself. The other thing I need to check
is if the rewards available is more than

to show the highlight at all. The way
that I can bind to a VM value while also

custom function.
So now you can see I've created a set
highlight text function in the crew pass
button widget.
That function takes in an integer which

Then with that integer I can do all the

So when you have a more complex use case

I'll give more examples of when it makes

Now, let's talk about a couple of the
options that you have when you're
setting up your bindings.
The first is the directionality of the
binding.
The first option you have there is one
time to widget.
One time is a little bit of a misnomer
because it can actually change when the
VM changes.
But as long as the VM stays constant,
then the value will only be set once. So
it's more like one time per VM.
One way to widget is the most common
setting that we use here. That's going
to send a value from the VM to the
widget and update it whenever the value
changes on the VM.
Two-way and one-way to view model are
rarely used on Fortnite, but an example
would be text entry or checkboxes where
the user is setting a value on the view
the widget and we need to send that
value back to the VM.
The next setting that you have on
bindings is around timing.
When it's unchecked, this defaults to
auto, but you can override with
immediate or delayed.
The only time I've really had to
override here is to choose delayed
because this can sometimes help if
you're having race condition issues.
All right, now let's talk about
conversion functions.
Conversion functions are another way
that you can set up your bindings, and
they're a very handy tool.
And thanks to conversion functions, you
might not need to create a custom
function in your widget like I showed
you earlier.
There were around 1,250
conversion functions included in Unreal
Engine 5.5.
Basically, what these functions do is
convert one value to a different kind of
value.
So, let's say your data for controlling
the visibility of a widget is based on a
bool. You can't directly bind a bool to
a widget visibility because those are
two different types of properties.
So then you might think, well, I guess I
need to create a custom function in my
widget to determine how I want to
interpret that pool into a visibility of
your choice. But that's not necessary.
With a conversion function, you can make
that distinction right in the binding.
So in this example on the screen, we're
using the two visibility conversion
function to translate our bound boolean
value into a visibility.
The visibility options that I've set

not hit testable for true and collapsed

they could also be variable based on a

All right. Now, I'd like to talk about a

this pitfall is what if I need a

Right around now, you might be realizing
that all the binding examples I've shown

So, here's an example of where you might

In the Fortnite season pass reward track

The setup that led to this bug is a

Conversion functions can be very
